project_metadata.paper_title: Validating predictions of burial mounds with field data: the promise and reality of machine learning
project_metadata.journal: Journal of Documentation, Vol. 80, No. 3, pp. 601-623
project_metadata.research_context: Evaluation of a machine learning approach using convolutional neural networks (ResNet-50) to detect Bronze and Iron Age burial mounds in 1-metre resolution IKONOS satellite imagery of the Kazanlak Valley, Bulgaria. Assesses whether computational object detection models trained on legacy datasets can reliably identify archaeological features, with field validation testing predictions against ground-truth survey data.

implicit_arguments.trigger_text: self-reported success rates were misleadingly high
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The authors imply that F1 scores and other internal validation metrics are unreliable indicators of real-world model performance without external field validation, and that the ML community may be systematically overestimating model effectiveness.
implicit_arguments.implicit_claim: Internal ML performance metrics (F1, precision, recall) can systematically overestimate practical utility when applied to complex real-world archaeological detection tasks

implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: By documenting that 63% of papers fail to mention negative aspects and only 6% discuss failures, the authors imply that the published ML literature presents an unrealistically optimistic view that may mislead practitioners.
implicit_arguments.implicit_claim: The archaeological ML literature systematically underreports failures and limitations, creating an overly optimistic impression that may lead to uninformed technology adoption decisions

implicit_arguments.trigger_text: Expert researchers, or even novice volunteers, would have been more reliable
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: This statement implies that for certain archaeological detection tasks, human cognition—even untrained—may outperform sophisticated ML models, challenging the assumption that automation necessarily improves on manual methods.
implicit_arguments.implicit_claim: The cognitive flexibility of humans for pattern recognition in complex, variable environments may exceed that of current transfer learning approaches for certain archaeological applications

implicit_arguments.trigger_text: the model seemed to select bright lines and edges (forest, roads), rather than round shapes
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: This observation implies that the CNN learned spurious correlations from background features rather than the actual target morphology, suggesting fundamental limitations in how transfer learning extracts relevant archaeological features.
implicit_arguments.implicit_claim: Pre-trained CNNs may learn to detect incidental landscape features that correlate with training data rather than the archaeological target features themselves

implicit_arguments.trigger_text: the return on additional time spent developing the ML approach diminishes rapidly
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The authors imply that there is a resource threshold beyond which further ML investment becomes less efficient than alternative approaches, challenging the assumption that more sophisticated ML always yields better results.
implicit_arguments.implicit_claim: For modestly-resourced archaeological projects, the cost-benefit analysis may favour manual or crowdsourced approaches over continued ML development investment
